entry.title: Navigating the SAP Learning Help Center: Your Gateway to Seamless Learning Support!
entry.content:
Embarking on a journey through SAP’s extensive ecosystem can be both exciting and challenging. Whether you’re an experienced professional looking to enhance your skills or a newcomer eager to explore SAP’s offerings, having dependable support is essential. That’s where the SAP Learning Help Center comes in—a comprehensive resource designed to support learners at every step of their SAP learning journey.

 

This centralized portal offers a wide range of resources, including step-by-step guides, troubleshooting advice, and detailed FAQs, all aimed at improving your learning experience. From onboarding assistance to resolving technical issues, the Help Center is your one-stop destination for reliable support.

Before submitting a support ticket, please take a moment to explore our Help Center resources for quick answers and solutions

In this blog, we will explore the key features of the SAP Learning Help Center, highlight common scenarios where learners seek assistance, and share tips on how to make the most of this valuable resource.

 

Common Scenarios for Creating a Support Case with the Learning Team:

You may need to open a support case in the following situations:

  1. Difficulty scheduling exams
  2. Requests to update names on existing certificates
  3. Questions regarding subscription or renewal processes
  4. Seeking guidance on choosing the right certification path
  5. Issues related to student subscription accounts

 

How to Create a Case with the Learning Team

To create a support case, please follow these steps:                 

Visit the SAP Learning Help Center.

 

Select Create a new case or check the status of an existing one.

 

Click on Create a case, which will open the SAP Learning Self Service(s) page.

Click Create Case again to open the form, then fill in the required details:

    • Subject
    • Service Category
    • Description
    • Email of affected user (optional)
    • Attach any relevant files (if applicable)

Submit the form.

 

 

Once submitted, your case will be created, and you will receive an email notification linked to your S-User ID with the case details.

Additional Resources:

  • Knowledge Base Article (KBA): 2404504 - How to get help with the SAP Learning Hub or SAP Training Center - SAP for Me
  • Points of Contact | SAP Community

 Thanks for reading!

We hope you found this helpful. Please note that the Customer Interaction Center is always happy to guide you on any of the mentioned processes and assist you with any queries you may have!

We would love to hear from you, let us know what you think?

Read more Customer Interaction Center blog posts Here!

 If you have any questions, please feel free to ask us in the Q&A All Questions in Customer Experience | SAP Community and All Questions in Support Services | SAP Community

entry.title: Incorrect purchase info record unit migration by Migration cockpit
entry.content: During create Purchase Info Records with conditions by using the Migration Cockpit, an incorrect unit was migrated for specific condition types. The correct unit is %, but migrated as USD. So the amount became very large. eg. The same Combination of "material+ supplier+ purchasing organization+ plant" have 2 condition types: Y001: Gross Price [USD]; Y051: Duty [%] When using migration cockpit, Y051 amount incorrect migrated as 97568%. This has led to two issues. The first is incorrect data migration, which needs to be corrected to the right data. The second is that in the template, the Condition Sequence Number field is written as 1 and 2 , means including two different conditions: Y001 and Y051. However, in the system, the purchase condition record number in the KONP table for Y001 and Y051 is the same, but the item number is different. In the A017 table, the condition record number only has the condition type Y001.This results in the inability to open the Y051 detail page when viewing the purchase information record with ME13. However, when create a purchase order and standard cost estimate, the condition records of Y001 and Y051 can be automatically set in. Who can tell us how to modify the errors caused by unit errors and multiple condition types?

entry.title: Re: Doubt for optimize abap code in BADI
entry.content:
Hi,

I don't see any of the "is_ee_org_ass_repl_req-org_assignment" internal table's fields to be used in the queries. Then why to put in the loop at all. Result is always going to be same, isn't it? You can move the queries outside the loop.

If you've not shared the whole code and I assume you're using few fields from the internal table "is_ee_org_ass_repl_req-org_assignment" for selecting the data using those selects, then you can have below two options

1. Use for all entries or ranges to select data in one go and then use READ statements within the loop.
2. If you're on new ABAP version, then you can do a join also to fetch the data in one go.
this will eliminate the select within the loop.

Regards.

entry.title: UNTECO via Program Not Updating RESB Table (Unlike COR2 Standard Log)
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are trying to reverse TECO (UNTECO) for a process order programmatically.

We are currently using the FM STATUS_CHANGE_INTERN to change the order status from TECO back to REL.
While this successfully updates the system status (JEST), it does not update the dependent tables, especially RESB, which remains with the deletion indicator ( XLOEK='X' ).
In the standard transaction COR2 → Cancel Technical Completion, SAP automatically reactivates the reservations (clears XLOEK) — this does not happen when using the FM.

We have already tried the following options:

  1. BAP_RESERVATION_CHANGE
    → Returns the message “Reservations automatically created. No manual changes possible.”
    Hence, we cannot use this for order-generated reservations.

  2. BDC for COR2
    → As per SAP Note 2729700, COR2 is not batch-recordable, so BDC is not an option.

Our goal is to achieve the same effect as COR2 → Cancel TECO, i.e.,

  • Reverse TECO status, and

  • Automatically clear the deletion indicator in RESB (and other dependent updates).

Has anyone implemented an alternative approach or identified an internal FM/BAPI that replicates COR2’s Cancel Technical Completion logic in a custom program?

Any guidance or standard FM suggestion would be appreciated.

Thanks & Regards,
Vineeth Nekkanti
SAP ABAP Developer

entry.title: Join SAP Usability Testing Sessions at SAP TechEd Bangalore - Influence your Product Experience
entry.content:
Join our live usability testing session at SAP TechEd Bangalore on November 25-26, 2025.

Usability testing offers a unique opportunity for SAP users to engage directly with the SAP product and development teams. In a focused 60-minute one-on-one session, you’ll interact with product screens and evaluate whether the buttons, terminology, and features meet your expectations and workflow needs

If you've ever thought, "Why can’t I just click here and make it work?" — this is your chance to influence exactly that. Your feedback helps us create intuitive, user-friendly solutions that better support your business.

Prerequisites for participating in usability testing at SAP TechEd Bangalore

  1. To be able to participate, you need to be an attendee at SAP TechEd Bangalore.
  2. You need to have experience with using the product for which you’d like to participate in a Usability Test.

What you need to know about the registration process

  1. We use the Bookings app to manage registrations for Usability Tests at SAP TechEd. Your data will be stored in our forms on the booking platform. To the extent that the entered information is personal data, SAP will use it in accordance with this privacy statement.
  2. Use the links below to register for the Usability Test Stations at SAP TechEd Bangalore and pick one of the available time slots for the test session.
    Please arrive at the Usability Test Lab 10 minutes before your scheduled time.
  3. Please sign up with your business email address – it will only be used for scheduling your test session; you will not receive marketing because of this registration.
  4. Email notifications will be sent from Usability Testing Lab Participant Interest Form <UsabilityTestingLabRegistration@sap.onmicrosoft.com>  Please check your SPAM/JUNK folder in case you do not receive the confirmation emails.
  5. Interested in future online user research opportunities after SAP TechEd?
    To receive invitations, please complete the registration form for the SAP User Research Panel.
    If you don’t sign up, your contact information will be deleted four weeks after the event in accordance with our data privacy policy.

Usability Test Stations

Usability Test Station 1: 
Integration Flow generation using AI & Groovy scripts readiness for Integration Cell runtime


Test the AI feature for creating integration flows from scenario descriptions (including Groovy script steps) with error handling. Evaluate Groovy script readiness for the upcoming Integration Cell runtime and explore integration flow creation via Joule using high-fidelity prototypes.

Target audience: Participation in this usability test is restricted to users of SAP Integration Suite who have experience with developing integration flows.

Potential roles include:

  • Integration Developers
  • Solution Architects,
  • SAP BTP Consultants
  • Business Process Experts 

Register here as a tester

 

Usability Test Station 2: 
Test Conditional Task Chains and Port Connections in SAP Datasphere, BDC

We’re inviting experienced SAP Datasphere Modelers and Integrators to participate in a usability testing session for the enhanced Task Chain workflow.

This session focuses on evaluating the new ability to react to task outcomes and define conditional execution paths using dedicated ports:

  • Success (green)
  • Error (red)
  • Any (blue)

These enhancements aim to give users greater control and flexibility in orchestrating complex workflows. Alongside these, participants will also explore other new capabilities introduced to improve error handling and configurability.

A key focus of this session is to assess both usability and the durability of interactions — ensuring that the experience remains stable, intuitive, and efficient across varied use cases.

Your feedback will help us refine and improve our workflows even further.

Target Audience:
Participants need to have experience with cloud implementations and end-user knowledge to participate.

Potential roles include:

  • SAP Datasphere Modeler / Integrator
  • Consultants
  • Developers

Register here as a tester


Usability Test Station 3: 
End-to-End Agentic User Journey for Building Processes with Joule

In this session, participants will experience and evaluate a future-state, agentic user journey for building business processes using Joule, the AI assistant integrated within SAP Build Process Automation. The focus is on exploring how Joule can support users through end-to-end process creation by providing intelligent suggestions, automating repetitive steps, and enabling seamless collaboration with key stakeholders. We aim to understand usability, clarity of guidance, efficiency gains, and how well Joule integrates into existing SAP Build Process Automation workflows. Participant feedback will help refine the interaction model and identify opportunities for enhancing agentic assistance in real scenarios. 

Target Audience:
Participants need to have experience with cloud implementations and end-user knowledge to participate.

Potential roles include:

  • Regular SAP Build Process Automation users
  • Process Designers
  • Citizen Developers
  • Automation Leads
  • Consultants
  • Business Process Experts

Register here as a tester

Usability Test Station 4: 
Smart Helper - An agent you define; actions you approve; Easy Fill: Copy, Paste, and Done in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

This session aims to evaluate the user experience and effectiveness of two AI-powered capabilities: Smart helper- we will evaluate how easy it is to get started, how clear control and approvals feel, and how overall usability and user experience are perceived; Easy Fill - we will evaluate how easy it is to use and if there is something missing. 

Target Audience:
Participants need to have experience with cloud implementations and end-user knowledge to participate.

Potential roles include:

  • Business Process Experts
  • Solution Architects
  • IT Administrators
  • SAP S/4HANA Solution Consultants
  • Developers

Register here as a tester


Usability Test Station 5: 
Evaluate WalkMe Onboarding Experience on SAP SuccessFactors

Evaluate how users access WalkMe tours and engage with the onboarding experience for SuccessFactors features. To evaluate how effectively users can complete key SAP SuccessFactors tasks using WalkMe tours by identifying any usability, clarity, or content issues and gathering feedback to improve the overall experience.

Target Audience:
Participants need to have experience with cloud implementations and end-user knowledge to participate.

Potential roles include:

  • Business Process Experts
  • Solution Architects
  • IT Administrators
  • SAP SuccessFactors Solution Consultants

Register here as a tester

Usability Test Station 6: 
Supercharge your SAP Fiori elements app development with SAP Fiori tools and AI

SAP Fiori tools are evolving to allow companies to dramatically improve developer efficiency by integrating intelligent, AI-enabled features and editors into the development environment. SAP Fiori tools are designed to lower the entry barrier for new teams while providing the advanced capabilities and flexibility that experienced developers demand. In this usability session, you can experiment with some of our early AI-driven features, provide feedback on our tools and our vision, and directly influence our direction for the next generation of intelligent development tools.

Target audience:
Participation in this usability test is restricted to users with experience developing Fiori apps using SAP Fiori tools (which are a part of SAP Build Code). Potential roles include:

  • S/4HANA Developers
  • Web Developers
  • Fiori Developers
  • Fiori Elements Developers
  • SAP Developers
  • Product Owners
  • Users of the Annotation Modeler
  • Other front-end developers leveraging web technologies

Register here as a tester


Disclaimer (for SAP TechEd 2025, Bangalore usability testing interest list)
By registering you are expressing interest to join the participant list for usability testing at SAP TechEd 2025, Bangalore. Registration does not guarantee participation. Selected participants will be notified separately by email once they meet all eligibility criteria required to take part in the sessions and provide feedback. Due to limited seats, we cannot accommodate all registrants; priority will be given to applicants who meet specific selection criteria (for example: product experience, implementation involvement, end-user knowledge, valid licensing status, and other program requirements).

entry.title: Need help in allocation using advance formulas
entry.content:
perform allocation in a loop based on the below requirement

Allocated value in 2027 = (total base value 2026- allocated value 2026)*ratio

Allocated value in 2028 = (total base value 2027- allocated value 2027)*ratio

Allocated value in 2029 = (total base value 2028- allocated value 2028)*ratio

this will continue till 2037 year. 

Inside the foreach loop (Date)               
                
versionWVRegionExpAudit trailPeriodAmount  versionWVRegionExpAudit trailPeriodAmount
FC1##SBSB_FEES202612345  FC1wv1Reg1SBamount_after_allocate2026500
          wv2Reg2SBamount_after_allocate2026500
                
                
Compute the base amount for Y+1, so for 2027       20272027 Allocation computation: Ratio*(Total_amount_2026-Allocated amount 2026)      
         versionWVRegionExpAudit trailPeriodAmount
         FC1wv1Reg1SBamount_after_allocate202712345-500(I7-R7)(12345-500)
                
                
                
Compute the base amount for Y+1, so for 2028       20282028 Allocation computation: Ratio*(Total_amount_2027-Allocated amount 2027)      
         versionWVRegionExpAudit trailPeriodAmount
         FC1wv1Reg1SBamount_after_allocate2028(Base amount in 2027 - allocated amount in 2027)

entry.title: How to Handle Posting Issues for Billing Documents with Using Joule
entry.content:
Background Information

As a billing clerk, managing billing documents with posting issues can be frustrating sometime. Fortunately, Joule can streamline the process, making it more efficient and less stressful to resolves the posting issues. 

Posting issues often arise when billing documents cannot be posted to the financial account due to errors like closed posting periods. Common errors include accounting errors (F5/286 and F5/903), which occur when the billing date falls outside the open period.

Joule is an AI copilot designed to enhance interaction with SAP business systems. Joule delivers a unified user experience across SAP's solutions, offering conversational interactions to streamline information access, automate business processes, and improve both employee and customer satisfaction. For more information, see What Is Joule.

Prerequisites

  1. Ensure you have the Sales - Billing Documents business catalog (SAP_SD_BC_BIL_DOC_PC) assigned. The Billing Clerk role template (SAP_BR_BILLING_CLERK) includes this catalog by default. 
  2. Set up Joule in your environment. For more information, see Initial Setup. 

Implementation Details

Follow the steps below to try out this feature:

  1. Log in to your Fiori Launchpad as a Billing Clerk. 
  2. Launch Joule. The method for launching Joule differs depending on your platform. See Using Joule | SAP Help Portal.
  3. Ask Joule to find out billing documents with posting issues. You can narrow down your searching results by specifying criteria such as document type, issue type, or sales organization. Note that only the billing documents with accounting access error will be listed here.
  4. Use the Post button or chat commands to post a document. Only one document can be posted at a time.
  5. Review the error message for more details.
  6. As an alternative solution, you can adjust the billing date to a valid date using the quick buttons. When the posting error is resolved, the document will be automatically posted. You can open the billing document to confirm the changes.

By following these steps, you can efficiently manage and resolve posting issues, ensuring a smooth billing process. 

Watch the following video for step-by-step instruction:

entry.title: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Factoring Process without Dedicated Scope Item - App and Process Guida
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I have a question regarding the implementation of a factoring process in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

**Background:**
- Customer uses 2-party factoring (immediate payment type)
- Customer wants to use standard functionality WITHOUT the dedicated Factoring scope item (due to additional cost)
- Manual workaround using standard apps and postings is preferred

**Business Flow:**
1. Invoice issued to customer: ¥1,000,000 (accounts receivable created)
2. Factoring company purchases receivable: Cash received ¥900,000 (¥100,000 factoring fee)
3. Customer pays to our bank account: ¥1,000,000 (we hold this on behalf of factoring company)
4. We transfer to factoring company: ¥1,000,000

**Proposed Accounting Entries:**
1. AR creation (Feb 10):
DR: Accounts Receivable (Customer account) 1,000,000
CR: Revenue 1,000,000
→ App: Customer Invoicing (F-22 equivalent)

2. Factoring purchase & cash receipt (Mar 10):
DR: Bank 900,000
DR: Factoring fee expense 100,000
CR: Accounts Receivable (Customer account) 1,000,000
→ App: Manual Journal Entry (FB01 equivalent)?

3. Receipt from customer (Apr 15):
DR: Bank 1,000,000
CR: Deposits payable 1,000,000
→ App: Post Incoming Payments (F-28 equivalent)?

4. Payment to factoring company (Apr 16):
DR: Deposits payable 1,000,000
CR: Bank 1,000,000
→ App: Post Outgoing Payments (F-53 equivalent)?

5. Clearing of "Deposits payable"
→ App: Manual G/L Account Clearing (F1579)

**Questions:**
1. Is this flow technically feasible in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition? Additionally, are the App IDs I mentioned (F-22, FB01, F-28, F-53, F1579) correct for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, or should I use different apps?

2. Specifically, can we clear customer-specific AR (created via customer invoicing app) directly with a manual journal entry including the factoring fee difference as shown in entry 2?

3. If this approach is not possible, what alternative process would you recommend? Please include:
- Which apps to use (with App IDs if possible)
- Accounting entries for each step

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

Best regards

entry.title: Creating an Import Data Connection to an On-Premise MS SQL Server
entry.content:
In this blog we’ll discuss complete steps that allows you to import data from an on-premise SQL database to SAP Analytics Cloud .

Here, Our Data source is SQL Database from which the SAP Analytics Cloud is connected using the SAP Analytics Cloud Agent and SAP Cloud Connector.

It is recommended that the Cloud Connector, SAP Analytics Cloud agent are installed together on a dedicated server, and not a personal computer. This helps to ensure that multiple users can use an import data connection without experiencing slowness or downtime.

Below are the steps for Import Data connection for On-premise SQL Database –

1. Check the connectivity between SAC agent server and SQL DB on the required port.

telnet <MS SQL SERVER> 1433

2. Installing and Configuring SAP Cloud Connector and JVM on a linux server.

  • To install a cloud connector refer the link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/ae39ab60b1154c179e2baabd26aa249c.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=release

  • Make sure a latest JVM version is installed on the Cloud Connector server.

  • To open the SCC, enter: https://<hostname>:8443 in a browser, where the <hostname> is the hostname of the machine on which the connector is installed, and the port number is the one configured during installation. The default port number is 8443
  • Click on “Add subaccount” and enter the details of the SAC subaccount , which you can find on SAP Analytics Cloud. To find the Subaccount details of SAP Analytics Cloud :

You must use a System Owner account to perform the following steps. If you don't know who the system owner is, log on to SAP Analytics Cloud and from the side navigation, choose Security > Users. 

 In the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Account section, enter account ID. In our case SAP Analytics Cloud tenant was hosted on a non-SAP data center, hence our account ID is an email address.

 When the account ID is accepted, account information will be displayed.

Once all the details are entered, your subaccount addition in your Cloud Connector will look like below:

  • Configure System mapping.

Add the internal host name of the Tomcat server where the SAP Analytics Cloud agent is running.

The default Tomcat port is 8080 and the default HTTPS port is 8443.

Enter the virtual host and port so that the internal host name and port are not exposed. 

Agent is reachable.

Add resource.

3. Installing and configuring SAP Analytics Cloud Agent on Linux Server

  • Make sure you have agent installed. To install it you can refer https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/7c35129451f5432194773adac7f89598.html

You can verify the installation by opening the following URL in your browser: http://<Host>:<Port>/C4A_AGENT/deploymentInfo

The version of the SAP Analytics Cloud agent installed is displayed.

  • Also verify if JRE, Tomcat are installed on the Agent server.

  • Log on to SAP Analytics Cloud with an administrator account.
  • From the side navigation, choose System  Administration -->  Data Source Configuration.
  • In the On-Premise Data Sources section, Add a new location.

You can connect to multiple locations that have on-premises data sources. Each location that you add should already have a Cloud Connector installed and configured on it.

You can also leave the Location ID blank to create a Default Location. This Default location will correspond to your subaccount on the SAP Cloud Connector with a blank Location ID.

  • Make sure Enable Agent is set to ON and enter the virtual hostname and Port that you created during Cloud Connector Configuration along with the Agent username password specified in tomcat-users.xml file.

4. Make sure JDBC driver is installed.

  • Install JDBC drivers if not already based on the JVM version.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/connect/jdbc/download-microsoft-jdbc-driver-for-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver17

The jar files can be in any location on your server as long as the properties file includes the correct file locations.

We kept it in SAC agent installed directory and gave permission 777 and ownership as sidadm:sapsys.

  • Create a properties file that specifies the paths to JDBC drivers you want to use and place it in the same file system where the SAP Analytics Cloud agent is installed. The properties file can have any name, such as DriverConfig.properties.

  1. You must restart the SAP Analytics Cloud agent, using the Java option -DSAP_CLOUD_AGENT_PROPERTIES_PATH since the agent is installed on Linux.

Navigate to tomcat/bin.

Run the shutdown.sh script.

Open the catalina.sh file in the tomcat/bin directory and find the line where Java options are set. Modify this line so that the -DSAP_CLOUD_AGENT_PROPERTIES_PATH option is included and points to your .properties file.

 

Run the startup.sh script.

5. Creating the Import Data Connection in SAC.

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Process Automation - How to get currectUser...
entry.content:
Hi izni,

the username you see (the secret code) is actually the global user ID of the user, who started the workflow.

It is part of IAS user setup.

IAS can be setup to have other values as Global user ID, or example the email could be used.

However it will anyway not solve your requirement, as it is the user ID of the user who started the flow, not the currently logged on user.

To get this, you must use some BTP user info API, or IAS API. I think this is tricky, haven't solved it myself yet.

Johannes

entry.title: MRP Planning Issue
entry.content:
Hi all,

There is a unique business requirement where the finished material should not be planned (MRP Type – ND), but its dependent materials should still be planned (MRP Type – PD).

Here’s the scenario:

  • When a sales order is created for the finished material, the requirement should appear in MD04.
  • The system should plan the dependent materials accordingly.

However, when we maintain MRP Type as ND for the finished material and create a sales order, the schedule line category defaults to CN (No planning), which makes sense — but in this case, the sales order is not visible in MD04.

Now, in transaction VOV5, there’s an option to maintain the schedule line category.
If we manually assign schedule line category CP, will the demand be visible in MD04?
And if it is visible, will the dependent materials (with MRP Type PD) be planned accordingly?

If not, I’m looking for a workaround that can meet this requirement — where the finished material itself isn’t planned, but its components are.

Appreciate any inputs or experiences from the community.

Thanks & Regards,
T. Hemant Kumar

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H2025 Release: Enhancements to Dependent Information Importing You Need to Know
entry.content:
The enhancements in the second half of 2025 bring change, excitement, and often discomfort. For consultants, it means extended hours of analysis and extensive testing.

As we prepared for our analysis and customer release presentations, the enhancement "A Dependent Can Only Be Linked to One Employee'' had captured our attention.   

Organizations frequently have employees who share the same dependents, and these relationships are displayed on their profiles. The new validation will prevent imports attempting to link a dependent to more than one employee unless the specified method is followed.

After reviewing the Release notes, we noticed the SAP Note:

If you still wish to link the same dependent to multiple employees, you can create multiple persons for this dependent in the system.

Let's test this!

Scenario: We have an existing dependent who is assigned to an employee in the organisation.  We want to link the same dependent to another employee.

Employee with an existing dependent.

Problem:

Prior to 2H2025, to assign this dependent to another employee, we were able to link this dependent using the Personal Relationship import using the existing person-id-external field.

Using the existing person-id-external for this import after the release will result in an error.

Solution: Starting in 2H2025, the following steps must be implemented using a new external person ID for the dependent.

1. Prepare, Validate, and Import Biographical Info import file

Creating a new person-id-external for the dependent is mandatory.

2. Prepare, Validate, and Import Personal Relationships import file

Dependent is now linked to the second employee.

3. Prepare, Validate, and Import Personal Information

Imports for National ID, Address Info can be imported using the same process once the above steps are completed.

An enhanced validation has also been introduced which ensure dependent's Personal Information records and Address Information records are aligned with the start date of the dependent's Person Relationship records.

After our review and analysis of the 2H2025 release notes, we have identified necessary validations, enhancements, and UI changes. 😊 Let's continue exploring, reading, and as always, monitor the 2H2025 Known Issues!

Thanks for reading!

Ashlin

entry.title: How to Bulk Modify Calendar Event Context Filters Using Scripting
entry.content:
The Calendar in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a powerful framework for orchestrating planning processes, tasks, and workflows across teams. Each calendar event or process carries context filters — such as Date, Version, or Proficenter etc. — that define the specific slice of data being worked on by a team or user.

In some cases, administrators or power users may need to update these context filters in bulk, for example when moving from one fiscal year to another.

While this can be done manually using the Calendar List workspace (where multiple events can be selected and edited together), alternatively scripting provides a faster, automated way to achieve the same — especially when you need to apply changes dynamically.

This approach is inspired by the SAP Community blog written by @mike688 
Experience Sharing – How to Batch Modify the Assignees of Calendar Events Using Scripting in SAC, which demonstrates how to modify event assignees in bulk using the Calendar Integration API.

In this post, we extend the same idea — but instead of assignees, we modify dimension context filters for multiple events at once.

Option 1 – Editing Multiple Events via the SAC UI

You can update context filters directly using the Calendar List workspace:

Steps:

  1. Navigate to Calendar → List workspace.

  2. Select multiple events that you want to modify.

  3. Click Edit Events.

  1. Choose Context, and update filters such as Date, Version, or Category.

This method works well for manual batch updates, especially when the changes are straightforward and performed occasionally.For detailed reference, see SAP’s documentation: Editing Multiple Calendar Events at Once

Option 2 – Automating Context Filter Updates Using Scripting

The Calendar Integration API in SAC allows developers to access and modify multiple calendar tasks and processes programmatically.

You can learn more about this API and its supported operations in the official documentation: SAP Help – Calendar Event API Reference

Below is an example that demonstrates how to batch modify Date context filters for all child events of a process. You can also modify the same script to change other dimension context filters also.

Example Scenario

Suppose your planning calendar has multiple child tasks for FY2022.
You now want to update all these tasks to FY2025 automatically.

Step 1:  Accessing the EventID of a Process

To view the event ID of an event, go to the Event Settings dialog and choose Show Details. 

Step 2: Create a story and add the below code to the story widget.

Prerequisite: Add a Calendar Integration Technical Object

Then, paste the following script:

 

// Step 1: Get main process event
//Replace XXXXXXX with Process Event ID.
var root = CalendarIntegration_1.getCalendarEventById("XXXXXXXXXXXXX");

if (root === undefined) {
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Warning, "Invalid event ID.");
    Application.hideBusyIndicator();
    return;
}

// Step 2: Check event type
if (root.getType() !== CalendarTaskType.Process) {
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Warning, "Only Process type events can be modified.");
    Application.hideBusyIndicator();
    return;
}

// Step 3: Get children
var process = cast(Type.CalendarProcess, root);
var childIds = process.getChildren();

console.log("Child event IDs:");
console.log(childIds);

var targetYear = "2025"; // Enter Target new year for the child event 

// Step 4: Loop through each childs
for (var i = 0; i < childIds.length; i++) {
    var childId = childIds[i];
    console.log("Processing child ID"+childId);

    var ev = CalendarIntegration_1.getCalendarEventById(childId);
    if (ev === undefined) {
        console.log("Skipping invalid child->"+childId);
		       continue;
    }

    // Step 5: Get context filters
    var ctx = ev.getContextFilters();
    console.log("Context filters for child:");
    console.log(ctx);

    // We can’t assign null → use flag and index instead
    var hasDateFilter = false;
    var dateFilterIndex = -1;

    for (var j = 0; j < ctx.length; j++) {
        var f = ctx[j];
        if (f.members && f.members.length > 0 && f.members[0].dimensionId === "Date") {
            hasDateFilter = true;
            dateFilterIndex = j;
            break;
        }
    }

    if (hasDateFilter === false) {
        console.log("No Date filter found for"+childId);
        continue;
    }

    var dateFilter = ctx[dateFilterIndex];
console.log("datefilter");
	console.log(dateFilter);
    // Step 6: Remove old Date filter for the child event
    var removed = ev.removeContextFilter(dateFilter);
    if (removed === true) {

		console.log("Removed old Date filter for -> " + childId);

    } else {
        //console.log("Could not remove Date filter for:", childId);
        continue;
    }

    // Step 7: Build new Date filter dynamically
    var modelId = dateFilter.members[0].modelId;
    var hierarchy = dateFilter.hierarchy;

	var newDateFilter = ArrayUtils.create(Type.CalendarContextFilter); 
			

	newDateFilter = [{
    hierarchy: {
        id: "FYQP",
        description: "FYQP"
    },
    members: [
        {
            dimensionId: "Date",
            id: "[Date].[FYQP].[Date.FISCAL_YEAR].[" + targetYear + "]",
            description: targetYear,
            displayId: targetYear,
            modelId: modelId
        }
    ]
}];

    // Step 8: Add the new Date filter
  ev.addContextFilter(newDateFilter[0]);
  console.log("Added new Date filter (" + targetYear + ") for" + childId);
}

// Step 9: Done
Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Date context filters updated successfully for all child events!");
Application.hideBusyIndicator();

 

API Methods Used

MethodPurpose
getCalendarEventById()Fetches a specific event using its ID
getChildren()Retrieves all child events under a process
getContextFilters()Returns all context filters for the event
removeContextFilter()Removes an existing context filter
addContextFilter()Adds a new context filter dynamically

Summary

The Calendarevent API in SAP Analytics Cloud provides a rich set of methods that go well beyond modifying context filters.
You can reuse the same structure to perform a variety of automation and maintenance actions across the planning calendar events.

By combining UI-based editing and scripting automation, SAC administrators can achieve both flexibility and efficiency in managing planning calendars.

 collection is IFormCollection

try
 {
     var fileStreams = new Dictionary<string, byte[]>();

     foreach (var formFile in collection.Files)
     {
         if (formFile.Length > 0)

             // Copy file stream
             var memoryStream = new MemoryStream();

     SLAttachment sLAttachment = await ServiceLayer.Connection.PostAttachmentsAsync(fileStreams);
     attchmentEntry = sLAttachment.AbsoluteEntry.ToString();


     
 }
 catch (Exception ex)
 {

     return new JsonResult(new { success = false, error = ex.Message });
 }

entry.title: S/4HANAの新リース会計基準対応について

entry.title: Re: How do I configure a custom sales workflow in SAP Sal...
entry.content:
Hi Suheb,

To automate in SAP Sales Cloud that, after 30 days, an opportunity automatically moves to the next sales phase or triggers the creation of a task, you need to create a scheduled (time-based) workflow rule. This rule can be based directly on the creation date or on a custom date-type field that controls when the action should be executed. In the first case, you simply define the condition “creation date + 30 days” and configure the action to either update the sales phase or create a task for the responsible user. In the second, more flexible approach, you can create a custom field such as “Next Action Date,” which is automatically updated (via workflow) with the current date plus 30 days each time the opportunity changes phase or is modified; then, a scheduled workflow rule is created so that when the date in that field is reached, it executes the corresponding action to update the phase or create a task.

Best regards,
Fernando

entry.title: Re: SAP Integration Content API - Is it possible to view all process direct endpoint value
entry.content:
Hi!

I need the same functionality: a list of all ProcessDirect endpoints alongside their corresponding iFlow names. Did you find a solution to your problem? Unfortunately, the /ServiceEndpoints API doesn't provide ProcessDirect endpoints. From my perspective, you could do the following:

  • Get all packages with the /IntegrationPackages API.
  • For each package, retrieve the list of all artefacts: /IntegrationPackages('MyPackage')/IntegrationDesignTimeArtifacts.
  • For each iFlow artefact, download the content: /IntegrationDesignTimeArtifacts(Id="MyIFlow", Version="active")/$value.
  • Unzip the content and read the file: src/main/resources/parameters.propdef.
  • Select all entries from the node: <param_references> where the attribute_id contains ProcessDirect.
<param_references> where the attribute_id contains ProcessDirect.
<reference attribute_category="Sender1" attribute_id="ctype::Adapter/cname::ProcessDirect/vendor::SAP/version::1.1.2/attrId::address" attribute_uilabel="Address" param_key="address"/>​
  • You can fetch the endpoint, which relates to the attribute param_key, from the file: src/main/resources/parameters.prop.
#
Tue Sep 09 13:24:51 UTC 2025 
address=/myEndpoint
​
  • Alternatively, use the API /IntegrationDesignTimeArtifacts(Id="MyIFlow",Version="active")/Configurations and search for the parameter key with the same value as param_key.
"ParameterKey": "address",
"ParameterValue": "/myEndpoint",​

I could not find an easier solution.

entry.title: Develop Full-Stack ABAP Applications in SAP Business Application Studio
entry.content:
The SAP Business Application Studio provides several extensions designed to streamline the development of business applications for the SAP Intelligent Enterprise.

Among these extensions is the CDS Graphical Modeler, which enables SAP business developers to visually design Core Data Service (CDS) models. Previously, this extension was available for SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) development projects.

However, with the release of SAP BTP ABAP environment 2508 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, corresponding to ABAP release 9.16, we have integrated the CDS Graphical Modeler with ABAP. This integration allows developers to create ABAP projects using the CDS Graphical Modeler to conveniently design ABAP-compliant CDS models for various scenarios in a remote ABAP system.

Ultimately, you can now build full-stack ABAP applications in SAP Business Application Studio. Once you've created an ABAP project, you can model business objects, generate ABAP CDS artifacts, integrate a user interface, and deploy your application to the appropriate environments, such as SAP BTP ABAP environment or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Curious how this works? Check out our documentation on SAP Help Portal for detailed instructions: Develop Full-Stack ABAP Applications in SAP Business Application Studio.

But you’re short on time or just looking for a quick peek? Keep reading! 😉

1. Set Up Your Full-Stack ABAP Project:

In the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create right above the project list and select Create from the drop-down menu. This opens the Create Project dialog.

Project creation screen with options for Application, Automated Process, and Business Site, highlighting Application with a "Next" button.

In the Create Project dialog, select Application, click Next, select Full-Stack, advance with Next, and finally select Full-Stack ABAP (SAP Business Application Studio).

"Full-Stack ABAP (SAP Business Application Studio)" option is selected for creating a project with a "Next" button available.

Advance with Next and specify the target ABAP system and configure the project details.
Once the project is created, a Core Schema Notation Model is created in the remote ABAP system, and the remote ABAP package path is added to the workspace. The project then opens in the Storyboard.

2. Model Your Application:

From the Storyboard, you can model your ABAP application using the CDS Graphical Modeler to define and visualize your ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) business objects, projections, and services relevant to your application development.

Storyboard offers options to create a business object, projection, service, or UI application with corresponding plus buttons.

 Choose + in the Create an entity field to add the business object entities and define their relationship for the business service.

Note: Next to the Business Object modeler, you see your CSN file. This file resides on your ABAP system in the package you created previously. This file is used by the modeler to store your model. You should not edit this file manually since this can damage the integrity of the model.

Proceed with adding projections to specify which elements of a business object are exposed in the business service.

Add a business service and select which entities to expose in the service.

Storyboard shows the relation of business objects, projections, and services and an option to create a new UI application.

You are now all set to generate the ABAP backend artefacts from the modeled business objects, projections, and services. Close the Business Services modeler and return to the Storyboard.

3. Generate ABAP CDS Artifacts:

Once you have modeled your ABAP application, you need to generate the ABAP development objects based on the data model created with the CDS Graphical Modeler, including DDIC tables, CDS views, metadata extensions, and service definitions.

From the Storyboard, choose Generate and follow the steps in the wizard to perform validation checks and complete the generation process.
As a result, a read-only RAP OData UI service is generated and available in the service catalog. On the ABAP side, the development objects are activated, and the service binding is published.

4. Add a User Interface and Deploy Your Application:

As a last step, you need to create a user interface for your RAP service by generating a SAP Fiori UI application that you can then deploy to an appropriate environment, such as SAP BTP ABAP Environment or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

From the Storyboard, choose + in the UI Applications field to open the SAP Fiori Generator wizard and provide the required inputs for your UI development. To deploy the application, choose Deploy from the Application Information tab.

 

And that's it! You've successfully developed a full-stack ABAP application in SAP Business Application Studio—quickly and effortlessly in just a few steps.

What do you think of it? We would love to hear your thoughts! Share your feedback in the comments below.

entry.title: Re: Group reporting + data collection + SAC - SAP Public...
entry.content:
Hi,

Think it might be difficult for you.

In Public Cloud you are not able to create additional chart of accounts. All your 15 clients would have the same Y1 standard. You will be able to create additional FS items but with 15 different clients... 

You will be able to create multiple versions, one for each client, to separate transactional data access but you need to be strict with your naming convention to create a close to viable authorization setup.

For GRDC you will have only 1. There can only be one connected GRDC. This means all input forms are shared: client 1 can look and change the layout of client 2. You don't authorize on individual forms or folders but on access to the Fiori tile.

Then if you have that the client will have super admin users and perhaps someone to maintain users and roles these you might have difficulties restricting not to have any access between your clients.

I can see you properly have some hosting revenue but you might  be better of recommending each of your clients to have their own public cloud.

Br

Martin Jul

entry.title: Re: difference between C_S43_2022 and C_TS413_2021
entry.content: I’ve passed both exams, and from my experience C_S43_2022 is the better option now. It reflects the more current S/4HANA Asset Management scope, while C_TS413_2021 is older and already retired. The updated content in C_S43_2022 aligns more closely with what you’ll actually see in real S/4 projects, so if you’re a Maintenance/Reliability engineer, that’s the one I’d recommend.

entry.title: Re: Professional service Projects
entry.content:
Hello @sanne_larsen 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Blogs: 4E9-New Project Billing Configuration and Process, Project Billing for Customer Projects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Professional Services in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2302

Links: Event-Based Revenue Recognition for Fixed Price Service Orders

Customer Projects with Event-Based Revenue Recognition

To summarise, in public cloud, the choice between Periodic Service and Fixed Price Service projects defines how and when your revenue is recognised.

  • If you have ongoing subscription-type engagements (e.g., managed services), where your revenue is recognised periodically based on elapsed time or incurred costs, then Periodic Service will be the ideal solution for you.
  • However, if you are focused on project-based engagements, where the revenue is recognised based on every achieved milestone or upon fulfilment of specific deliverables, then Fixed Price Service is the better fit.

If your customer’s business is shifting toward deliverable-based billing, you should define new projects where you use the Fixed Price Service setup. However, both models can also coexist if you segment your project billing items appropriately.

Manage Project Billing (helps you check contract type) and Run Revenue Recognition (helps you simulate accounting results) can help you review and simulate revenue timing

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Outlook for 2602 - 'AI-assisted permit management'
entry.content:
The 'AI-assisted permit management' innovation will help an Environmental Manager by significantly accelerating and simplifying the process of handling environmental permits. The process works in three main steps:
1. Import & Setup: The manager will import the environmental permit as a PDF document into the system.
2. Header Identification: The AI will automatically detect header information from the document's first page to help set up the permit's general data in the system.
3. Requirement Extraction & Task Proposal: The AI will extract compliance requirements from the permit text and automatically proposes corresponding operational tasks, such as data collection or reporting.

With the help of this innovation the manager will be able to review, accept, or deny these proposed tasks. This reduces manual effort, minimizes human error, lowers operational costs, and helps ensure compliance to avoid potential penalties. Stay tuned for the 2602 release!
